body:
Statinamic require a minimal boilerplate, in order to provide you some flexibility. , you can just run the following:

# The boilerplate

To get the default boilerplate, copy statinamic/src/boilerplate into a (fresh) local directory.

Feel free to adjust the package.json to your need. Just keep the scripts start and static.

When you have the boilerplate in place:

$ npm install --save-dev statinamic

For npm@3+ (to get required peerDependencies):

$ ./node_modules/.bin/statinamic setup

Note: You can use $ statinamic directly by adding ./node_modules/.bin to your PATH. It’s a good way to avoid global npm package while still being able to use bins from local node_modules.

# More explanation about the boilerplate

The default boilerplate:

  • initialize your bundles ( client + static ) with:
    • your layout components
    • some routes
    • a store to keep data in memory
  • create your build script so you can:
    • define your configuration (eg: webpack loaders to add your favorite css preprocessor)
    • run the dev server ((babel-)node build --server --dev)
    • build the static version for production ((babel-)node build --static --production)

You might as well need to:

  • write or reuse React components
  • tweak webpack configuration in the build script so you can consume images, svg, css or whatever you want.

# Linting

ADD DEFAULT RULES IN boilerplate

{ “parser”: “babel-eslint”, “env”: { “browser”: true, “node”: true, “es6”: true }, “ecmaFeatures”: { “modules”: true }, “rules”: { } }

https://github.com/MoOx/statinamic/blob/master/docs/package.json#L77-L79

# Hot reloading

In order to benefit of hot-loading and visual javascript errors, you can add this babel configuration

{
  "babel": {
    "stage": 0,
    "env": {
      "development": {
        "plugins": [ "react-transform" ],
        "extra": {
          "react-transform": {
            "transforms": [
              {
                "transform": "react-transform-hmr",
                "imports": [ "react" ],
                "locals": [ "module" ]
              },
              {
                "transform": "react-transform-catch-errors",
                "imports": [ "react", "redbox-react" ]
              }
            ]
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

You will need to install the appropriate packages

$ npm i -D babel-plugin-react-transform react-transform-hmr react-transform-catch-errors redbox-react

# Explanation about how the engine works

During the build process, markdown files are parsed, and transformed as JSON files (one part with the YAML header meta informations, one part with the body as HTML). So both client and server can easily consume markdown files (as json) in order to render pages from React components. That’s it !

On top of that you can add pretty much whatever you want to write styles the way you like (CSS, inlines styles…) and you can even create your own pages from plain React components. This generator is just an helper.

# Packages used

  • Babel for writing ES6 and ES7
  • Webpack for bundling,
  • Express with some middlewares for development:
    • Webpack Dev Middleware for watching
    • Webpack Hot Middleware for hot reload
  • React for writing UI
  • React Router for routing
  • Redux for handling application state (a better Fluximplementation)
  • Redux Dev Tools for awesome DX (developer experience).
  • react-helmet for handling pages meta tags (title and meta…)

# Some packages that might helps

  • react-transform-hmr for hotloading during development and some others friends from react-transform-boilerplate
  • tape for unit tests.
